awd_titl_txt: Research Initiation Award:  Quantifying the effects of ocean acidification on visual and auditory neurobiology in marine fishes
awd_abstract_narration:
Research Initiation Awards provide support for junior and mid-career faculty at Historically Black Colleges and Universities who are building new research programs or redirecting and rebuilding existing research programs. It is expected that the award helps to further the faculty member's research capability and effectiveness, improves research and teaching at his home institution, and involves undergraduate students in research experiences. The award to Hampton University has potential broader impact in a number of areas. The goal of the project is to investigate how possible changes in ocean acidification may affect visual and auditory neurobiology in marine fishes. Undergraduate students will gain research experiences. The project's interdisciplinary approach ensures that the principal investigator and the undergraduate scholar-researchers will make significant impacts in this rapidly emerging field that will be of broad interest to the marine science community.

The goal of the project is to apply electrophysiological techniques and morphological analyses to assay the effects of increased carbon dioxide concentrations that are representative of projected changes over the next century on the form and function of marine fish visual and auditory systems. The effects of both acute and chronic aqueous carbon dioxide exposure will be studied on the morphological development of visual and auditory sensory structures, the functional performance of auditory and visual systems, and the capability of a gamma-aminobutyric acid A receptor antagonist to alter potential sensory deficits during acute and chronic acidification using fishes from diverse phylogenies, geographic regions, and life histories. While resulting behavioral changes have been documented, the extent to which the physiological function of fish neurosensory systems is altered as a consequence of ocean acidification, and the morphological changes and functional deficits it may cause, remains largely unknown.

por.por_cntn:
PROJECT OVERVIEW:  This Research Initiation Award enabled the development of an interdisciplinary neurosensory ecophysiology laboratory at Hampton University to examine how projected changes in environmental conditions over the next century may affect the form and function of fish sensory systems. Specifically, this project applied electrophysiological techniques and morphological analyses to examine the effects of increased CO2 concentrations that are representative of projected changes over the next century on the morphology and physiological function of marine fish visual and auditory systems. This project examined the effects of both acute and chronic aqueous CO2 exposure (i.e. acidification) on the: (1) morphological development of visual and auditory sensory structures, (2) functional performance of auditory and visual systems, and (c) capability of a GABAA receptor antagonist to alter potential sensory deficits during acute and chronic acidification using fishes from diverse phylogenies, geographic regions, and life histories. The OANeuro project enhanced research capacity and provided critical infrastructure that will facilitate continued research by the PI, his peer-group collaborators, and undergraduates on questions at the organism-environment interface beyond the lifetime of the award. 

STATEMENT OF INTELLECTUAL MERIT: Atmospheric CO2 levels projected over the next century will result in levels of ocean acidification that can cause physical and behavioral changes in marine organisms, including potentially significant changes in neurosensory systems of marine fishes. The OANeuro project significantly advanced mechanistic understanding by applying morphological and electrophysiological techniques via the comparative method to demonstrated deficits in performance and changes to sensory organs of fish visual and auditory systems following acute and chronic exposure to increased atmospheric CO2 levels. Visual speed was slowed in CO2 exposed fishes, affecting the ability to resolve fast moving objects. Auditory performance was significantly worse in CO2 exposed fish than those held at current atmospheric levels, suggesting that sound-producing fish under high CO2 exposure regimes may experience disruptions to reproductive strategies that rely on vocal communication with mates. Four peer reviewed manuscripts resulted from this work, with up to five additional potential manuscripts slowed by the pandemic and thus still in development.

BROADER IMPACTS OF THE PROPOSED ACTIVITY: The OANeuro project's broader impacts included: (1) its focus on the recruitment, support, and professional development of undergraduate researchers from underrepresented groups in STEM disciplines; (2) the development of the PI’s research capacity and infrastructure at an HBCU via the creation of an interdisciplinary neurosensory ecophysiology laboratory capable of addressing emerging frontier questions in the geosciences; (3) fostering a culture of interdisciplinary research among students and faculty at an HBCU, majority institutions, and federal agency collaborators; and (4) student mastery of quantitative reasoning, critical thinking, and communication skills regarding anthropogenic impacts on marine ecosystems and sustainable stewardship of living resources and ecosystems of the future. Throughout this project, special emphasis was placed on written and oral communication skills via the development of student capstone theses, student and faculty conference presentations within international geoscience societies, and publication of results in peer-reviewed journals of high impact. During the lifetime of this award, one senior thesis was successfully defended, four underrepresented undergraduates had summerlong research experiences and two students had within-semester research experiences, culminating in four poster and four oral presentations at national and international conferences.  The PI applied the neurosensory infrastructure and early data from this project in a successful NSF CAREER Award proposal, the fourth in the history of Hampton University.
